newsitem.title: INDONESIA: FEATURE-Muhammad Ali trades punches for charity work.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE-Muhammad Ali trades punches for charity work.

text.p: Despite a 10-year illness that has left him almost unable to speak, boxing legend Muhammad Ali still retains the good-humoured arrogance that has made him one of the most publicised figures in modern sporting history.
In his heyday of the 1960s and 1970s it was Ali's claim to be "the greatest" boxer ever that won him blanket media coverage and sobriquets like "The Black Superman".
Today he tours the world promoting his Muhammad Ali Foundation in a bid to fight world hunger -- and still draws a crowd.

Arriving in Indonesia this month to donate 100,000 meals to a Jakarta hospital, the 54-year old Ali showed glimpses of his former expertise, exhibiting his trademark shuffle in a mock punch-up with airport security guards.
Every Indonesian newspaper carried pictures of the former champion on the front page the following day.

But his bravado masks a decade of suffering from Parkinson's Syndrome, an illness of the central nervous system. He is unable to walk properly and speaks very slowly, preferring to stay quiet in public.
But Ali obviously continues to enjoy the self-publicity that he first showed a flair for after beating Charles "Sonny" Liston to take his first world heavyweight title in 1964.
Immediately after the fight, the 22-year-old outsider known as Cassius Clay told the world that he had joined the "Nation of Islam" and was to be known from then on as Muhammad Ali.

Although his ability to "float like a butterfly and sting like a bee" led Ali to lift the world boxing title on three separate occasions, it was his genius at creating a larger than life image outside the ring that gave him a truly international profile.
"Today there are no Joe Fraziers, no George Foremans...No Muhammad Alis," the three-times champion told a news conference in Jakarta in a barely audible whisper.

In Indonesia to promote his fight against hunger, Ali could not resist a dig at today's boxing greats. When asked how he would deal with current heavyweight champion Mike Tyson, the ex-champion did not speak but pummelled his left palm with his right fist.
The audience was left in no doubt of his answer.

These days Ali's energies are channelled towards a very different pursuit. Working with Vitapro Foods Inc of Canada, which produces a dehydrated food product of high nutritional value, the former boxer says he wants to help the hungry all over the world.
Vitapro chairman Yank Barry, acting as Ali's spokesman, said that together with the Muhammad Ali Foundation they hope to feed 100 million people within two years.
"Now he has a new fight. He's fighting world hunger," Barry said of Ali.
Barry himself is no slouch at the celebrity game. He sang the one-time hit single "Louie Louie" with The Kingsmen before abandoning music for business.
He said that both he and Ali wanted "to pay something back to society" after years of international stardom.

The Muhammad Ali Foundation and Vitapro teamed up in July this year with the international relief organisation CARE to ship food to a half-million refugees caught up in a civil war in the West African state of Liberia.
Ali's foundation has also been involved recently in aid projects in Japan, Saudi Arabia and his native United States, Barry said.
Ali says that his desire to help starving people is part and parcel of his strong religious faith.
In 1967, he refused to serve in the Vietnam War because of his adoption of Islam, which led to the stripping of his world title.
He won it back in 1970 after a court battle to establish the justice of his refusal.
Ali won the world crown for a second time fighting George Foreman in Zaire in 1974. He became the only man to win the heavyweight title thrice after he beat Olympic gold medalist Leon Spinks in 1978.
He finally retired from boxing in 1981.
Barry said that Ali, now married to his fourth wife Lonnie, is coping well with his illness.
"On good days, he is great. In Atlanta he was tired," Barry said, referring to Ali's emotion-racked appearance at the inauguaration of the Atlanta Olympic Games earlier this year.
"When Ali does talk, it is quality words," he added.
